name: NPR
text: ISIS fighters tore Kamo Zandinan's 4-year-old daughter Sonya from her arms in 2014. Zandinan, now a refugee in Canada, recently returned to Iraq to meet the 10-year-old girl she believes is Sonya. https://t.co/X94TfjkDqa

name: NPR
text:
RT @kgounews: Eight months into the COVID-19 pandemic, masks remain a flashpoint in Oklahoma. That’s flummoxed public health officials, who thought a relatively minor inconvenience to inhibit the spread of an airborne virus would not become a political talking point.

https://t.co/tuok4vWAlm

name: NPR
text: RT @905wesa: More than 34,000 Pennsylvanians tested positive for the virus over the past week--yet less than one-quarter of these people were successfully reached by contact tracers, according to state health officials. https://t.co/rHY7qt2VBd

name: NPR
text: RT @tamarakeithNPR: “Do it in a way that doesn't look like you're being political...Do it in a way that, where people will feel like this is being done for them, genuinely for them." @FrankLuntz told me. https://t.co/NDSzb5C90j

name: NPR
text: With the transition officially going forward, President-elect Biden will receive the summary of intelligence reports contained in the presidential daily briefs — including information about major national security threats. https://t.co/kFuBC7gBLI

name: NPR
text: Pfizer's nearly $2 billion coronavirus vaccine contract with the federal government excludes almost all intellectual property rights, forgoing leverage to use if the company engages in price gouging down the road. https://t.co/rDkHgKsLPR

name: NPR
text: Michigan Attorney General Dana Nessel confirmed Tuesday that her office is "actively investigating" threats against members of the Wayne County Board of Canvassers. https://t.co/NMKCDdES9m

name: NPR
text:
With the pandemic raging and many stores closed, the Salvation Army says it anticipates it will bring in half the donations it did last year.

Now, it's relying more on online efforts than ever before.
https://t.co/FmElJ2qyol

name: NPR
text: The U.S. government has agreed to freeze any planned deportations of the immigrant women alleging abuse at a detention facility in Georgia  https://t.co/MmKtwGBKvW

name: NPR
text:
The Strategic National Stockpile — which the U.S. has traditionally depended on for emergencies — still lacks critical supplies 9 months into one of the worst public health crises the country has ever seen, an NPR investigation finds.
https://t.co/VAvXnzhKaZ

name: NPR
text: For the weeks ahead, the scattershot approach to the pandemic — where each state or region is left to sort out the trade-offs — will likely define the U.S. public health response to recent coronavirus surges. https://t.co/PiarTczt3h

name: NPR
text:
In the era of quarantining and COVID-19, folks in other countries have figured out ways to hold safe, traditional holidays and celebrations. Here are some tips they've devised.
https://t.co/gMQd6IY3GQ

name: NPR
text:
State officials were flying over southeastern Utah looking for sheep as a part of a routine task. 

Instead, they found something straight out of a sci-fi movie. https://t.co/5cxEYb5hIL

name: NPR
text:
Vaccine expert Dr. Peter Hotez: "One of the questions I'm asked all the time is: 'Hey, doc, which vaccine are you waiting for?'"

"I'm going to take any of those vaccines made available to me that's authorized by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.”
https://t.co/amCzsVPtck

name: NPR
text:
Soul legend Don Bryant has been in the music business since the early days of rock and roll.

Watch him perform three songs at his special quarantine Tiny Desk concert.
https://t.co/7Pctvrk9j0

name: NPR
text: In order to truly turn the current surge in coronavirus cases around, epidemiologists say governments need to do more than just order people not to see friends and family. https://t.co/iT3WpBXzVA

name: NPR
text:
Ernest Grant, president of the American Nurses Association, says historic abuses like the Tuskegee Institute syphilis study left Black people with a distrust of vaccines. 

He's part of a coronavirus vaccine trial to try to change Black Americans' minds. https://t.co/hrqaaSbZtG https://t.co/ecTedu4b0R

name: NPR
text:
Operation Warp Speed's allocation-by-population policy downplays the role of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices — an independent group for the CDC.

The committee has proposed distributing COVID-19 vaccines based on high-risk groups. https://t.co/LE9WiFC810

name: NPR
text:
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell "knows how to pull all the levers. The organ is playing. And he's not only hitting the keys, he's doing the footwork," former Sen. Alan Simpson says. 

And McConnell is very aware of his fundraising prowess. https://t.co/PBk02nQfGy

name: NPR
text: Wisconsin has some of the highest coronavirus rates in the country; it also sold more than 800,000 licenses for this week's deer hunt. Three hunters tell @wuwmradio about how the pandemic has changed or canceled their families' annual tradition. https://t.co/pLXfiBvNyg

name: NPR
text: With the coronavirus spreading at record speed, it's still far from clear that even data-driven, tailored approaches will work, given the enormous reach of the virus and the coming holiday travel season. https://t.co/rgT9EEsm3Q

name: NPR
text:
With recent promising news from three COVID-19 vaccine trials, employers are now weighing whether or not to make the vaccine mandatory for employees to return to work.
https://t.co/zQdpyvlhVe

name: NPR
text:
Federal health officials could shorten their recommendation for how long people should quarantine to reduce the risk of spreading coronavirus from the current 14 days to as few as seven.
https://t.co/mnFhdndi6Q

name: NPR
text:
The 2020 presidential election saw the highest turnout rate since 1900.

And as of now, President-elect Joe Biden has earned 80 million votes — the most cast for any presidential candidate in U.S. history.
https://t.co/VYOmQj3zlm

name: NPR
text:
A North Korean man who says he's a former gymnast defected to South Korea this month by reportedly jumping a nearly 10-foot fence along the DMZ.

South Korean officials are investigating — and had him jump twice in their presence to prove he was capable.
https://t.co/hvBeqsSCoi
